column5: message
Merge branch 'master' of github.com:eholk/harlan into kd-trees
Build a better KD-Tree by recognizing that empty space is good.
Built a whole KD-Tree!
Added filter. Again, super sequential, but hopefully we'll improve it later.
Adding a very simple sequential span. Parallel versions to come later. (Issue #75)
Updating elegant-weapons
Factoring out eval-split stuff, finding best in all three axes
Added code to evaluate splits
Adding a missing nest case and fixing a typo
Fixing a test broken by the last change
Compute bounding boxes for a set of shapes.
Starting on a KD Tree example
Adding vectors library with vector-append macro
Fixing up xfail tags

Implemented transactional kernels.

Now kernels that fail due to allocation errors are automatically retried with a larger region size.
Some work towards detecting over-allocated kernels in the case of trees
Disabling Vicare in Travis CI (Issue #154)
Let cond take multiple expressions in the body.
Adding test cases I forgot about before.

Don't duplicate danger vector for kernels that also do vector references.

Fixes breakage from last checkin.

Issue #89

Track the danger vector and add allocation failures (at least for vector allocation).

Issue #89
Better reporting of danger names

Changing bench-dmm to output YML format.

Also extended the runtime with functions to introspect what is going on.

Adding map.

Issue #152

This doesn't support multiple arguments yet, due to deficiencies in the macro expander, but it's enough for the basic case.

Merge pull request #153 from blueridanus/patch-1

Fixed minor typo on README.md
Fixed minor typo

Add a read-line function (Issue #97).

This reads a line of text from a file as a string. The returned string includes the trailing newline character.

This leaks memory too, because strings are not region-allocated (Issue #149)

Being a bit more careful about memory.

This avoids some valgrind errors, and should hopefully help reduce memory corruption (Issue #150)
Better linting of ifs
Added a way for user code to signal their own errors. Also, better linting.

Add string equality that compares contents rather than just checking pointer equality.

Also add some more ASCII file input, namely floats and strings.

Get rid of the big monolithic languages file.

Individual passes all load reasonably quick now, but the whole thing takes a lot of time still.
Further splitting stuff up.
More splitting up libraries. This didn't make quite as much difference.
Further splitting up languages file for better performance. Shaved about 2 seconds off Harlan no-op time

Add run-fail testspec (Issue #26)

Also fixed a bug in remove-danger.

I want to add testing for specific messages before closing this bug.
Started giving a little prettier output on type errors.
Initial compile-fail testspec support (Issue #26)

Merge pull request #148 from kwadrat/master

Fix misspelling in Chez Scheme
Fix misspelling in Chez Scheme
Adding missing file.
Progress on the Accelerate Ray Tracer.

Add a hack that allows kernel-local regions as long as you never touch them.

This allows for a little progress on my port of the Accelerate ray tracer.
Working on a translation of the Accelerate ray tracer.
Removing JIT stuff, since it hasn't been actively developed in a long time. We may want to resurrect it on a branch.

Added a simple and slow STL file reader.

This will let us have more interesting ray tracing examples, among other things.
Importing Vicare format in compatability library.
Updating syntax for define in linter so that all tests pass now.
Check for duplicate identifiers in function definitions.
Starting on a lint pass to give more user-friendly warnings and errors.

Initial number from bench-dmm. Pretty slow right now.

Also fixed a bug that prevented using region data in kernel arguments.

Cleaning up .gitignore.

We haven't had garbage collection in a long time...
Adding an ignored build directory to keep from cluttering up my git repo when I'm working.

Starting on a scaled-up DMM benchmark.

I can't believe this one didn't actually exist yet.
Removing commented out code.

Remove the renaming step from parse-harlan. Fixes #138.

Also removed the stray chezscheme dependency to fix Travis.

Added verbosity levels. Use -vv to get the old behavior.

Fixes #131, fixes #142.
Really simple graph holography experiment.
More debugging information for when the macro expander screws up.

Dump out a few of the bodies and forces to see if the numbers are reasonable.

Also, reverse the direction of the force calculation, since we had them all backwards.
Attempting to bump up the region sized used for benchmarks.
Commenting out the rest of the raytrace benchmark in scripts.
Don't include bench-raytrace.kfc in build-benchmarks.
Added more READMEs.
Run and graph raytrace benchmark.
Draw BFS.
Added dot product plot
Added vector addition plot.
Generate nbody plot.
Added BFS benchmark.
Added NBody benchmark.
Added dot product to run-benchmarks as well.
Script to run the various configurations of add vector.
Added a script to build just the benchmarks from the OOPSLA paper.
Added a README for the frontend.
Expanding the readme file.
More teletype font!
Moving the build status icon.
Adding Travis Build Status Icon.
Adding more READMEs.
Cleaning out some cruft and improving the README.
Minor makefile cleanup.
Lowering the stride length in reduce, since Apple's OpenCL for CPUs struggles witht his.
Added a simplified variant of nested-kernels.kfc, but it still crashes in the same way.

Use lazy string concatenation for better time and memory behavior.

Here's an example of before and after compiling `raytrace.kfc`:

Before `print-c` rewrite.
```
(time (harlan-format-c c-expr))
    288 collections
    7036 ms elapsed cpu time, including 5050 ms collecting
    7040 ms elapsed real time, including 5060 ms collecting
    4432345360 bytes allocated, including 2673839984 bytes reclaimed
```

After `print-c` rewrite
```
(time (harlan-format-c c-expr))
    259 collections
    6331 ms elapsed cpu time, including 4891 ms collecting
    6333 ms elapsed real time, including 4884 ms collecting
    2189060096 bytes allocated, including 535211792 bytes reclaimed
```
Further memory reduction.
Splitting up languages.scm, which leads to significantly less memory usage.
Add flush-stdout.
Skip 0-length reads, since these are technically illegal according to OpenCL.
Merge branch 'master' of github.com:eholk/harlan
Added HARLAN_DISABLE_OPENCL_OPTS environment variable.
Ignoring lots of files I tend to have hanging around in my build directory.
Adding a #define so that SVNu64 gets defined by inttypes.h
Switching HSBencher to HTTPs for Travis.

Beginning of the rodinia benchmark in harlan.

Signed-off-by: Marcin Zalewski <marcin.zalewski@gmail.com>

Eric's fix to the "danger thingie."


Signed-off-by: Marcin Zalewski <marcin.zalewski@gmail.com>

Added reading of uint64_t integers.

Signed-off-by: Marcin Zalewski <marcin.zalewski@gmail.com>

Reading files for rodinia.

Signed-off-by: Marcin Zalewski <marcin.zalewski@gmail.com>
First attempt at updating for hsbencher 1.8
Add a missing u64 case.
Adding enough file I/O support to read integers.
Merge branch 'bigred2'
Activate raytrace bench
Modify bench-raytrace to follow the HSBencher protocol.
A ray tracing benchmark showing the cost of branch divergence.
three different surface constructors working in the raytracer.
Merge branch 'bigred2' of github.com:eholk/harlan into bigred2
Add bfs-color to bench list
Report memory transfer times as JITTIME
Make mandel size command line driven and add it to benchmarks
Fix arg parsing for add-vector.  Also further fix nbody
Fix arg parsing for nbody
Merge branch 'bigred2' of github.com:eholk/harlan into bigred2
Convert nbody
Fixed a bug in remove-recursion. Raytracing has two objects now, although they are not quite right yet.
Making css-selectors typecheck. Still fails to compile due to Issue #114.
generalize the length fix from before, since this will probably lead to hard to fix bugs again in the future.
minor: update submod
Switching back to HSBencher 1.6
Do things the simple way for test bench-add
WIP: hacking on multi-result but its having problems
Merge branch 'bigred2' of github.com:eholk/harlan into bigred2
Switch to table id
Fixed a bug where length did not always dereference the correct region to determine the vector's length.
Enable compilation when using full Chez Scheme.
Script tweak
perms
Update submod and add jenkins benchmark script
Tweaks for benchmarking
Enable compilation when using full Chez Scheme.
Hack for futuregrid
Makefile tweaks
Refresh the HSBencher script and add a cabal file and Make target for it
Merging with master
Commenting out verbose runtime logging.
Enough of this nonsense. xfailing css-selectors.
...and another paren matching mistake.
Fixing paren-matching mistake.

Fixing a type error in css-selectors.kfc

If we're lucky, this means Travis will finally be fixed.
Fixing installation scripts.
Add a few more harlani commands.
Avoid useless data transfers

Adjust Travis scripts to install only one scheme, and use parallel builds for vicare.

This will hopefully reduce our travis cycle times.
Add file and line number to OpenCL failures.
Follow the OpenCL spec better.

Display failure logs by default when running make check.

This will help us debug failures in Travis CI.
Deal better with vectors of ADTs inside of ADTs. Ground unconstrained type variables as int. Towards a more complete CSS matching algorithm.
Starting on a CSS Selector Matching example.
Updating elegant-weapons.

Add trace-pass and untrace-pass to harlani. Also made it more robust to unrecognized commands.

Fixes #132. Fixes #124.
Allow irrefutable patterns in arguments to define (Issue #127)
Be more robust in the face of multiple OpenCL platforms.
Pass u64 literals through the whole compiler.
rewrote remove-danger in nanopass.
Merging latest kernel-fusion changes.
Updating vector addition benchmark.
Fixing up dot product benchmark.
Merge branch 'master' into kernel-fusion

Added a color-based and a distance-based bfs.

The two BFS's could be merged and selected at run time.

Signed-off-by: Marcin Zalewski <marcin.zalewski@gmail.com>

Merged.

Signed-off-by: Marcin Zalewski <marcin.zalewski@gmail.com>
Merge branch 'kernel-fusion' of git@github.com:eholk/harlan into bigred2
Merge branch 'master' of git@github.com:eholk/harlan into bigred2
Cleaning up some output in the vector addition benchmark.
Working on a more robust kernel inliner.

Merged.

Signed-off-by: Marcin Zalewski <marcin.zalewski@gmail.com>
Change make-vector into a macro that generates kernels that we can optimize.

Modified bfs to work with distances.

This is an initial version.

Signed-off-by: Marcin Zalewski <marcin.zalewski@gmail.com>

On-GPU allocation of vectors. Fixes #67.

I'm breaking my rule of only checking in code that passes all the tests. I suspect these are OpenCL bugs, not cases where we are disobeying the spec.

Added u64_max and a definition necessary to make uint64_t work.

Signed-off-by: Marcin Zalewski <marcin.zalewski@gmail.com>
Only report the minimum region size once when controlled by an environment variable.
Let BFS accept command line arguments for the graph size.
Rewrote parse-int as a recursive function.
Updating elegant weapons to support unsigned integer literals.
Use .dylib for shared libraries on Mac. Fixes #104.
Split runtime into executable and library versions. Fixes #118.
harlani now uses rlwrap if available. Fixes #123.
Make harlani path-independent. Fixes #117.
Remove cKanren symlink.
Use #ifndef instead of '#pramga once'. Fixes #120.

Seriously turn down the let lifting so we get correct results on mandelbrot.kfc again.

Issues #116 and #56.
HARLAN_DEVICE is now case-insensitive, and it reports an error for invalid values. Fixes #115.
Add get-environment-variable. Fixes #100.

Update README.md

I'm building and running on Mavericks now too.
Added a string to number parser written purely in Harlan, but it's commented out because it crashes OpenCL.
Move int->float and float->int into the library.

Added str->vec to enable more powerful string handling (issue #102).

Added a new unsafe-cast primitive that lets us write conversion functions in the library.
Added command-line builtin. Fixes #101.

main is now in the runtime library and Harlan programs instead implement harlan_main.

Related to issue #101 and issue #92.
Better precision for nanotime.
Use new random library in bench-bfs.
Add print* and prinln*
Fixed a bug in remove-nested-kernels where not all kernels were being visited.
Report timing for nanopasses as well.
Error out on unknown command line arguments
Display usage information when the --help option is given.
Report more precise floating point values.
BFS reports timing. The graph is still too small for this to be interesting though.
Better reseeding of the random number generator.
Added Xorshift random number generator. Fixes #113.
Rename datatypes so constructor and type names don't clash. Fixes #94.
Add bitwise shifting operators.
Added a test to make sure we can use bitwise-xor.
Updating elegant weapons
Modernizing BFS.
Report OpenCL version as well.
Report OpenCL platform information too.

More language pruning.

M10 was entirely unused, so this is now commented out.
Comment out uglify-vectors-new, since it uses a now nonexistant language.

We aren't using M7.2 at all, so no point spending time macro expanding it.

Shaves about 13 seconds off compile time.
Pruning the languages slightly.
Remove src-tmp if it exists already.
Re-enable OS detection on petite.
Make petite be the default Scheme.
Tell Travis to test both Vicare and Petite.
Harlan now supports both Vicare and Petite, and this can be selected through an environment variable. Fixes #11.
Implemented path-* functions for Vicare, so harlanc can guess the correct file names now.
Add texinfo to the packages we install.
We need GMP for Vicare.
Switching to @akeep's nanopass fix.
Update Travis for Vicare.
Cleaning up debugging output.
Merging with master.
Save test output to stderr as well.
Updating link to OpenCL SDK.
Return color codes again.

Add an extra clause to Kernel, which is needed to ensure correct ordering.

We were probably generating incorrect call graphs before because of this issue.
Removing cKanren
Add a prebuild.ss file to give us finer-grained control over what we prebuild. We should expand this as Vicare gets more stable.
Updated the prebuild target.
Added some output flushing so we see everything we're supposed to from run-tests.
run-tests works with Vicare now.
Allow more things as invoke targets.
Added a test case for issue #56. This isn't quite sufficient to expose the bug, but it's a start.
Box complex kernel arguments. Fixes #105, fixes #109.
Pruning parsers to hopefully reduce memory usage.
Added another nanopass language to put remove-complex-kernel-args before lower-vectors (#105)

Travis doesn't actually have GPUs, so don't try to use them.

Revert "Test both CPU and GPU in Travis."

This reverts commit 9eebaea2c2281d9896f499ecfe32e20421007060.
Test both CPU and GPU in Travis.
The stack actually lives in the private address space.
Use __local pointers into the stack. Fixes #108
Parser no longer accepts return. Fixes #90
Another attempt at making Travis CI work (#107)
Rephrasing typedef to try to make this work on Travis CI
Update elegant weapons to put __global before the type name. (Issue #107)

Region variable passing is fixed, so this test works now.

Fixes #95.

Match caller and callee regions correctly. This avoids errors saying a function needed 4 parameters but only got 3, for example.

Also, disabled grammar verification, as the nanopasses are providing a lot of this verification for us now.
Allow invoke on match expressions. This chunk of code really needs to be refactored.
Following the OpenCL standard more closely for clGetDeviceIDs.
Add a new error reporting macro to get better reporting when OpenCL calls fail in the runtime.
Allow more things as invoke targets.
Added a test case for issue #56. This isn't quite sufficient to expose the bug, but it's a start.
Box complex kernel arguments. Fixes #105, fixes #109.
Pruning parsers to hopefully reduce memory usage.
Added another nanopass language to put remove-complex-kernel-args before lower-vectors (#105)

Travis doesn't actually have GPUs, so don't try to use them.

This reverts commit 9eebaea2c2281d9896f499ecfe32e20421007060.
Test both CPU and GPU in Travis.
The stack actually lives in the private address space.
Use __local pointers into the stack. Fixes #108
Parser no longer accepts return. Fixes #90
Another attempt at making Travis CI work (#107)
Rephrasing typedef to try to make this work on Travis CI
Update elegant weapons to put __global before the type name. (Issue #107)

Region variable passing is fixed, so this test works now.

Fixes #95.

Match caller and callee regions correctly. This avoids errors saying a function needed 4 parameters but only got 3, for example.

Also, disabled grammar verification, as the nanopasses are providing a lot of this verification for us now.
Removing legacy infer-regions pass.
Allow invoke on match expressions. This chunk of code really needs to be refactored.

Compiled iota.kfc using Vicare. (#11)

There are some pretty nasty hacks, and some functionality doesn't work. Also, the Chez/Vicare-specific code should move into a compatability library so we can hopefully keep compatibility with either.
Updating nanopass to support vicare.
Following the OpenCL standard more closely for clGetDeviceIDs.
Add a new error reporting macro to get better reporting when OpenCL calls fail in the runtime.
Add a recursive tag to tests that use recursion in kernels so we can skip them to avoid locking up the machine on less robust GPUs.
Oops, also forgot the Travis CI support files.
Oops, we need to  first.
Enabling Travis CI
Defined a nanopass-language for just before uglify-vectors.
Merging with master.
pruned languages to remove unreachable nonterminals and terminals in lagnauges
Updating Nanopass. This shaved about 7 seconds off the Harlan compiler startup time.
WIP: towards a new intermediate language for the nanopassification of uglify-vectors.

Towards boxing kernel arguments.

This should probably go earlier in the compiler though...

Issue #105

Removing the in-tree documentation, since they are out of date. For now we'll use the wiki as the official documentation.

Updated the readme with a link to the Harlan Wiki and the harlan-dev mailing list.
In-kernel errors basically do nothing right now. This is because we're not actually generating correct error paths. This lets the code keep running in non-error cases, but it's still not great.
Add some shading to the raytracer (#80)
Rendered a circle (there's no shading yet). Unfortunately, we have trouble passing ADTs to kernels as free variables.
More work on the raytracer. It compiles now, but we're getting the weird error about unitialized kernel arguments again.
Merge branch 'master' into raytrace
Started working on a ray tracer. Found a fixed a few missing match clauses, but there are still more to come.
Correctly generate invokes of lambdas. Fixes #103.
Performance tuning.
Working on reductions with lambdas for operators. Includes test cases for #103.
Display better information when harlani catches an exception.
Add an exception handler so halarni doesn't die on erroneous programs.

Added a really simple interactive Harlan compiler.

This lets us avoid paying the startup cost with each invocation of the compiler. Incredibly useful when we're writing applications in Harlan rather than working on the compiler.
Include text of runtime includes in generated OpenCL code. Resulting executables are now path independent. Fixes #23.
Better path independence regarding libraries.
Some fixes to make Harlan .so files actually usable.
Add unsafe-vec-ptr. Now we should have all the pieces to build a tolerable FFI.
Add a few functions to directly dereference pointers, so we can interact with foreign code better.
Tests pass with Intel OpenCL.
Remove some unnecessary tracing.

Added a color wheel test case. Also fixed a bug in the call graph generator that would include calls from kernels in functions.

There is still another bug where recursive calls are not always handled as they should.

Added a test to draw colored circles, making sure PPM output works.

Updated mandelbrot3 to fit in the default region size. This should work even with larger images, but region resizing is broken in kernels (#89, most likely).

Added kernel* to harlan-mode.
Update nanopass, update libdirs to use precompiled binaries if available.

Adding ppm support to the library, along with a more colorful version of Mandelbrot to test it.

mandelbrot3 crashes at the moment, probably related to region resizing issues.

println is now a macro.
Add a basic hsbencher setup.
minor: add a build target to precompile .so files

Added another lambda calculus interpreter that uses recursion directly.

This test exposes a few more bugs in the compiler

In-kernel recursion works even for non tail calls.

Fixes #96
Updating elegant-weapons

Working on recursion.

Added stacks, call-lives, etc.

Non-tail-recursive factorial compiles now, but the OpenCL compiler fails on the CPU. On the GPU, it runs, but it claims factorial 5 is 0, which it isn't.
A first approximation of call-live analysis
Added a test case that uses mutual recursion
First tail recursive function call in a kernel worked.
Move the call graph stuff later in the compiler.
Rewrite generate-kernel-calls with nanopass
Created a language for after hoist-kernels / before generate-kernel-calls.
Rewrite make-work-size-explicit in nanopass.
Rewriting make-kernel-dimensions-explicit using nanopass.

Move all the nanopass languages to their own file.

I'm not entirely sure this is a good idea.
Dump strongly connected components in the call graph as well.
Added the ability to dump the call graph as a DOT file. Also, found a bug in the trampolined interpreter.

Added code to build the callgraph.

With the new explicit stack design for recursion, it migh make sense to do this after desugar-match, since that introduces a lot of new functions. They shouldn't affect the strongly connected components though.

Use floats by default, with a compiler flag to use doubles.

This is to work around the fact that doubles are not well supported on all hardware.
Hello world should print on its own line.
Working on self application.
Add a test case illustrating false recursion.
Merge branch 'master' into lambda
Merging lambda into master.

All test cases pass on CPU.

Closes #76.

CPS, trampolined interpreter runs on GPU.

There are problems with kernels receiving structs as arguments in Apple's CPU OpenCL implementation...
CPS, tramplined interpreter works using Harlan lambdas. It's a little tricky due to the lack of dynamic types.

A CPSed lambda calculus interpreter that uses Harlan lambdas.

Took some fixes in closure free variable handing, and we finally had to insert function prototypes.

Fixes #37.
Lambdas (and probably ADTs in general) can close over vectors now.

Merge pull request #91 from lkuper/patch-1

Typo fix in README.md.
Typo fix in README.md.
Fixing Makefile to call the new run-tests wrapper.
Adding a license.
This benchmark ran, if I bump the minimum region size up to 100,000,000.
bench-add-vector now takes the average of 10 runs.
Added timing to the lambda benchmark, including a new time-s function to report the time in seconds instead of nanoseconds. Also, removed some of the print logging.
Setting constants for benchmarking on Delta.
Cleaned up the error formatting code, added support for another error handler.
WIP: working on debugging bench-lambda
Added a --no-kernels compiler option, which converts all kernels into for loops.
WIP: Trying to close over vectors.
Lambdas can return lambdas.
Fixing the environment problem, but now typechecking will need to be updated.
Updating elegant-weapons
WIP: ran in to the problem with not having the environment in time. Need to break the dependency.
Lambdas can have free variables
Lambdas work in kernels.
The lambdas don't even conflate!
First lambda test case passes!
Generate dispatch function.
Update later passes so we get all the way to an executable now.
A little more progress on generating ADTs for Lambdas. I still need to create the dispatch functions though.
Updating elegant-weapons.
A tolerable uncover-lambdas pass.
The beginnings of the remove-lambdas pass.
Defined enough of a language to parse the lambda test case.
Added nanopass as a submodule and a skeleton remove-lambdas pass that will use it (#79)
Added an invoke form for calling lambdas. Typechecking works well enough for a first pass. We're ready to add the lambda removal pass. (#76)
Lambda gets up to typechecking now.
Renaming test cases so that we can use lambda for the tests that actually test harlan lambdas.
Update README.md
This benchmark ran, if I bump the minimum region size up to 100,000,000.
bench-add-vector now takes the average of 10 runs.
Merge branch 'wip' of github.iu.edu:eholk/harlan into wip
Added timing to the lambda benchmark, including a new time-s function to report the time in seconds instead of nanoseconds. Also, removed some of the print logging.
Setting constants for benchmarking on Delta.
Cleaned up the error formatting code, added support for another error handler.
WIP: working on debugging bench-lambda
Added a --no-kernels compiler option, which converts all kernels into for loops.
This version actually runs, but it can only do one expression. We're probably doing some size calculations wrong...
Working on a lambda calculus benchmark (#87). Some debugging is needed.
Using the record-case that's now in Elegant Weapons.
Added kernel*. Fixes #86.
Yet another macro expander. This one passes all tests and thus has no hygiene bugs that I'm aware of. Fixes #78.
Import graphics library in graphics tests.
Another failed attempt at a macro expander. This one uses some kind of mutable environment approach that never really panned out.
Removing a lot of the old macro cruft. Strangely, more tests pass now.
An attempt at an interpreter-style expander. It sounded elegant at first, but it ran in to the same hygiene issues as before.
Slightly better hygiene, but more broken tests. Uses a wrap structure to try to carry marks along.
Get rid of the unlikely names in the reduce macros. This exposes a hygiene bug that will probably need marks to fix.
An ugly hack to work around Apple's buggy implementation of sqrt in GPU OpenCL.
Fixed a typo in environment lookup
Updating elegant weapons
Hygiene for kernel. This was literally the same structure as hygiene for let. (#78)
Hygiene for match (#78)
Do hygiene correctly for let-region (#78)
Gensym the subst operator in the expander so that we can use subst as a name in user code.
Hygiene for define (#78)
for is now a macro. That's one fewer binding form. (#78)
Updating elegant-weapons.

Fixed some runtime and codegen bugs. All tests pass again.

Finally fixes #64.
Added a benchmark version of nbody.
Danger Words (Issue #64). Five tests fail, but it gives us much better performance and we're in crunch time, so we'll have to go with this for today.
Add unsafe-vector-ref, since we don't have optimizations yet to prove vector references are safe in many cases.
Tweak benchmarks to run better on delta.
Be more careful about copying regions back. This should reduce the large-region penalty.
Lazy memory transfers. Fixes #62.
Updating bench-add-vector
Handle nested kernels in return statements. This allows us to pass all tests with the fast reduce, although fast reduce isn't always fast.

Tweaking the memory allocation parameters, which have a huge impact on performance. With the fast reduce variant, GPU dot product is bound by the PCIe bus, which means we're on par with cublas. CPU dot product is pretty abysmal still though.
Working on a new reduce macro that will actually get some parallelism. Doesn't actually yield a performance improvement yet, but that seems to be due to absurdly slow memory transfers.
Only allocate device-backing buffers for the duraction of kernels. This simplifies the region code, and also means we won't run out of device memory as often.
Changing the sizes on the dot product benchmark.
Rewrote mandelbrot in modern Harlan. Much easier to read, and much more correct.
Fix a bug in let-lifting with lets on the right hand side.
Switch back to g++ so we can run on Delta.
Cleaner lambda calculus interpreter runs on GPU now. I had to shrink the minimum region size a bit because we allocate too many regions
Iterate to fix point when gathering kernel symbols. Lambda3 works with CPU, but not on GPU. Could be bugs in Apple's OpenCL.
Fixed a bug with the types when returning if expressions. Third generation lambda is almost complete, but it doesn't compile correctly yet.
Redoing lambda2 to be properly CPSed and next, trampolined. This will make for better presentation in the paper.
Lambda Calculus interpreter runs on the GPU!
Towards a data-structure trampoline... Still has two recursive calls to apply-k, which means we are doing it wrong.
Starting on a new lambda calculus interpreter. This just needs CPSed, trampolined and data-structurized, and we should be able to run it on the GPU
ADTs can point to other recusive ADTs!
Fix a minor bug in expand-primitives, and clean up nbody.

Printing for non-recursive ADTs (#72)

Recursive ADTs will take some more work, due to the additional region parameters. We should probably just support true polymorphism or overloading and make print be a library/generated function.
Unxfailing the linked list test. Adding another test to allow lists of lists, showing that we can properly nest recursive ADTs.
First version of a lambda calculus interpreter. OpenCL doesn't reliably handle (that is, fail correctly on) recursive functions.
Harlan can do linked lists now. This means ADTs are recursive. They aren't thoroughly tested, and may not be able to be arbitrarily composed, but they're pretty awesome. Closes #70. Closes #43.
Explicitly mark the ADT types.
Updating elegant-weapons
Parse recursive ADTs
Unxfailing a couple of tests that work again.
Align vector data to 8 bytes. This is necessary to work with vectors containing doubles.

Merge branch 'master' into jit
Un-xfailing print-if

In short, this commit fixes our print-if problem.  Check below the
fold to see what it actually does.

First, we disallow if-Exprs after lift-complex.  All ifs are Stmts,
and their results are set!'d to a variable so they may be used later.
However, since if-Exprs can return things of any type, the "result"
variable that is effected must also be of any type.  Since this
introduces the problem of initialization, we now allow a (let Type
Var) form that compiles to the C-style declaration "Type Var;".

In addition, remove-danger is moved way down in the compiler, but I
fear we must move it down even further... after infer-regions so that
our compiler is not slowed down in that bottleneck with much-bloated
code.
Our tests were failing without optimizations turned on because of a cata-form in insert-let-regions; let-regions should not be inserted inside of a kernel, of course.
Moved lift-complex back to after returnify-kernels, it cannot go lower than make-vector-refs explicit because kernel arguments disappear and cannot be lifted outside of the kernel body.  Oops!
